channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: How a Hong Kong Artist Got Fired From McDonald’s

item.title: A $7 billion global engineering and construction giant hired a new CEO—but he’ll make less than half as much as his former boss
item.description: Fluor tapped Jim Breuer to be chief executive after less than a year as chief operating officer and more than three decades at the holding company.

item.description: The World Anti-Doping Agency withdrew a defamation lawsuit and an ethics case against American officials critical of its handling of failed tests by m...

item.title: Trump Administration Abruptly Clears Out Migrants It Sent to Guantánamo
item.description: A transfer operation on Thursday repatriated 177 Venezuelans via a handoff in Honduras, while one migrant was brought back to U.S. soil.

item.title: Germany Is in Big Trouble
item.description: Its economy is trapped in a vicious cycle and nobody seems to know what to do about it.

item.description: Leaders of all six Gulf states will meet on Friday to strategize with Egyptian and Jordanian counterparts ahead of a broader Arab summit early next mo...

item.title: Malaysia Starbucks franchise holder triples loss on boycotts
item.description: Berjaya Food reported its fifth straight quarterly loss as Malaysian customers boycotted U.S. brands over America’s support of Israel.

item.title: DOGE and efficiency czar Elon Musk are less popular with Americans than the programs they’re slashing, poll reveals
item.description: In court, the administration says Musk isn’t in charge. Donald Trump just said the opposite.

item.title: Japan has the world’s second strongest passport. Just 1 in 6 citizens hold it
item.description: The weak yen—which has shed a third of its value in the past five years—is one factor deterring Japanese travelers from going overseas.

item.title: Elon Musk had his $100 billion Tesla pay package denied by Delaware courts twice. Now, one of the EV maker’s law firms wants to change state law
